awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Hybrid Professional Development to Enhance Teachers' Use of Bootstrap
awd_abstract_narration:
Integrating computing and mathematics appeals to various stakeholders for a variety of reasons. For the mathematics education community, computing offers an application of mathematics concepts that may strengthen teachers' and students' mathematical understanding; for the computer science (CS) education community, integration enables equitable access to computing education for all students; for state boards and districts, integration accommodates staffing and curricular constraints while targeting core learning objectives in multiple disciplines. Bootstrap is a nationally-deployed curriculum that integrates computer science and algebra. Bootstrap's current professional development (PD) program for math teachers is a 3-day in-person event which assumes that teachers are somewhat facile with algebraic functions. Both Bootstrap and the National Council for Teachers of Mathematics (NCTM)  have observed that some teachers have a weak command of functions. School districts would prefer a shorter in-person PD to reduce staffing costs and increase flexibility. This project will use a hybrid PD model to address both needs. Simultaneously, the project will research ways to tailor the online content to be effective for teachers who differ in their understanding of functions, goals for pursuing PD, and interest in mathematics, computing, math/CS integration, and student thinking. This Researcher-Practitioner Partnership team includes Bootstrap; NCTM (specifically its Math Forum team, which has expertise in on-line training); Brown University; Swarthmore College; the Oklahoma State Division of Secondary Mathematics and Computing Education and school districts in Texas. A total of 270 middle-school math teachers---a majority from rural areas or serving Native American or Hispanic students in our partnering regions---will participate in Bootstrap PD under this project. Assuming typical adoption rates, these teachers should reach 6,000 students within the project period alone. Building Bootstrap content into the Math Forum will expose thousands of NCTM's teachers to the potential of integrated math/CS curricula.

 The team will use design-based research to develop and deploy a hybrid PD model and online support community for Bootstrap teachers, augment Bootstrap PD to reinforce teachers' understanding of algebraic functions, and conduct quasi-experimental studies to inform the design of different pathways through the PD. This project will study how to develop teachers' understanding of CS while also strengthening their math proficiency. In particular, the project will explore the possibilities for CS to improve teachers' understanding of algebraic functions. The project also will study ways in which teachers' interest can be made visible and useful in improving engagement and learning in integrated CS and mathematics PD. The results should apply to integrative programs beyond Bootstrap, suggesting strategies to tailor PD to serve more teachers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many districts and schools want (or are required) to include computing in their curricula, but face challenges around staffing, expertise, or room in the curriculum. Integrating computing into existing courses, which leverages existing teachers, can address the structural challenges, but leans heavily on professional development to motivate and prepare teachers for this effort. This project studied two aspects of this professional development, using the findings to refine curricular materials for Bootstrap, an established project that specializes in integrating computing and data science into existing K-12 subjects. In addition to the Bootstrap team, other PIs included an educational psychologist who studies the development of interest (Ann Renninger) and two experts in online and collaborative learning experiences for math teachers (Annie Fetter and Steve Weimar). The project was conducted in Oklahoma, in close collaboration with the heads of Mathematics and Computer Science learning in the Oklahoma Department of Secondary Education.

Bootstrap connects math and computing by emphasizing the role of algebraic functions in both disciplines. Prior to this project, Bootstrap staff had noticed that many teachers had fallen into a procedural understanding of functions that made it harder to understand the connections to computing. One major component of this project lay in developing an online professional development module (5 hours spread over 5 weeks) to help teachers reflect on algebraic functions at a conceptual, rather than procedural, level. This module takes place before the main Bootstrap professional development workshop, and also serves as a cohort-building activity. It consisted of Desmos-based activities about functions, readings, and discussion among teachers.

The second major component involved studies about teachers? interests and confidence in bringing computing into their math courses. In prior work, PI Renninger had developed a 4-phase model of how interest develops. At a high level, the levels distinguish passive versus active engagement with a topic, seeking further opportunities to engage with a topic, and participating in helping others engage with a topic. Based on a combination of surveys and interviews with participants, Renninger and her team confirmed that the 4-phase model also applies to math teachers working with Bootstrap. The findings led to concrete modifications and enhancements to the Bootstrap professional-development model. These include conducting workshops over many shorter sessions so teachers could use materials in class before learning a new topic, making more use of Desmos activities (a familiar format for many teachers) to emphasize computing concepts as well as math concepts, and encouraging teachers to retake the workshops after initially trying the material to deepen their understanding. 

A third component involved laying the groundwork for integration of the Pyret coding environment into the Virtual Math Teams (VMT) online collaborative probelm solving environment. An initial proof-of-concept was created and integration work has been suspended while the Pyret interface is recoded, which will also improve integration with VMT.

Overall, we find that repeating the workshop leads both to deeper understanding of the concept of functions (teachers report seeing deeper connections between math and computing when doing the online component a second time) as well as increased interest and confidence in teachers with integrating these subjects. Many teachers do retake the workshops, something they would not do if they didn?t see potential and value in the approach. Many teachers are also excited to deepen their own understanding of functions. The work thus has impact on each of teachers, teaching, and students. Additional outcomes from this project include revised curricular materials for Bootstrap?s Algebra and Data Science curricula that emphasize connections to functions in more concrete ways and include forms of reflection activities (such as Notice and Wonder) that have proven powerful in math education. 

In terms of broader impact and broadening participation, the 50 teachers who participated in the project (some multiple times) were evenly split between urban, suburban, and rural districts (rural schools are an oft-underserved demographic in Oklahoma, even though 70% of schools are in such districts). The urban teachers represented schools and classrooms with diverse student demographics. The number of overall participants was much lower than we had originally hoped for due to the impacts of both the Oklahoma teachers strike in year 1 and COVID in years 2 and 3. We adapted to the smaller number of unique participants by doing more in depth studies with them over the multiple years that they attended professional development.
